speaker: ORLANDO
text: As I remember, Adam, it was upon this

speaker: ORLANDO
text: fashion bequeathed me by will but poor a thousand

speaker: ORLANDO
text: crowns, and, as thou sayst, charged my brother on

speaker: ORLANDO
text: his blessing to breed me well. And there begins my

speaker: ORLANDO
text: sadness. My brother Jaques he keeps at school, and

speaker: ORLANDO
text: report speaks goldenly of his profit. For my part, he

speaker: ORLANDO
text: keeps me rustically at home, or, to speak more

speaker: ORLANDO
text: properly, stays me here at home unkept; for call you

speaker: ORLANDO
text: that “keeping,” for a gentleman of my birth, that

speaker: ORLANDO
text: differs not from the stalling of an ox? His horses are

speaker: ORLANDO
text: bred better, for, besides that they are fair with their

speaker: ORLANDO
text: feeding, they are taught their manage and, to that

speaker: ORLANDO
text: end, riders dearly hired. But I, his brother, gain

speaker: ORLANDO
text: nothing under him but growth, for the which his

speaker: ORLANDO
text: animals on his dunghills are as much bound to him

speaker: ORLANDO
text: as I. Besides this nothing that he so plentifully gives

speaker: ORLANDO
text: me, the something that nature gave me his countenance

speaker: ORLANDO
text: seems to take from me. He lets me feed with

speaker: ORLANDO
text: his hinds, bars me the place of a brother, and, as

speaker: ORLANDO
text: much as in him lies, mines my gentility with my

speaker: ORLANDO
text: education. This is it, Adam, that grieves me, and the

speaker: ORLANDO
text: spirit of my father, which I think is within me,

speaker: ORLANDO
text: begins to mutiny against this servitude. I will no

speaker: ORLANDO
text: longer endure it, though yet I know no wise remedy

speaker: ORLANDO
text: how to avoid it.

speaker: ADAM
text: Yonder comes my master, your brother.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he

speaker: ORLANDO
text: will shake me up.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Now, sir, what make you here?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Nothing. I am not taught to make anything.

speaker: OLIVER
text: What mar you then, sir?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Marry, sir, I am helping you to mar that

speaker: ORLANDO
text: which God made, a poor unworthy brother of

speaker: ORLANDO
text: yours, with idleness.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Marry, sir, be better employed, and be naught

speaker: OLIVER
text: awhile.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Shall I keep your hogs and eat husks with

speaker: ORLANDO
text: them? What prodigal portion have I spent that I

speaker: ORLANDO
text: should come to such penury?

speaker: OLIVER
text: Know you where you are, sir?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: O, sir, very well: here in your orchard.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Know you before whom, sir?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Ay, better than him I am before knows me. I

speaker: ORLANDO
text: know you are my eldest brother, and in the gentle

speaker: ORLANDO
text: condition of blood you should so know me. The

speaker: ORLANDO
text: courtesy of nations allows you my better in that you

speaker: ORLANDO
text: are the first-born, but the same tradition takes not

speaker: ORLANDO
text: away my blood, were there twenty brothers betwixt

speaker: ORLANDO
text: us. I have as much of my father in me as you, albeit I

speaker: ORLANDO
text: confess your coming before me is nearer to his

speaker: ORLANDO
text: reverence.

speaker: OLIVER
text: What, boy!

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Come,

speaker: ORLANDO
text: come, elder brother, you are too young in this.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Wilt thou lay hands on me, villain?

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I am no villain. I am the youngest son of Sir

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Rowland de Boys. He was my father, and he is

speaker: ORLANDO
text: thrice a villain that says such a father begot villains.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: Wert thou not my brother, I would not take this

speaker: ORLANDO
text: hand from thy throat till this other had pulled out

speaker: ORLANDO
text: thy tongue for saying so. Thou hast railed on thyself.

speaker: ADAM
text: Sweet masters, be patient. For

speaker: ADAM
text: your father’s remembrance, be at accord.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Let me go, I say.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I will not till I please. You shall hear me. My

speaker: ORLANDO
text: father charged you in his will to give me good

speaker: ORLANDO
text: education. You have trained me like a peasant,

speaker: ORLANDO
text: obscuring and hiding from me all gentlemanlike

speaker: ORLANDO
text: qualities. The spirit of my father grows strong in

speaker: ORLANDO
text: me, and I will no longer endure it. Therefore allow

speaker: ORLANDO
text: me such exercises as may become a gentleman, or

speaker: ORLANDO
text: give me the poor allottery my father left me by

speaker: ORLANDO
text: testament. With that I will go buy my fortunes.

speaker: OLIVER
text: And what wilt thou do—beg when that is

speaker: OLIVER
text: spent? Well, sir, get you in. I will not long be

speaker: OLIVER
text: troubled with you. You shall have some part of your

speaker: OLIVER
text: will. I pray you leave me.

speaker: ORLANDO
text: I will no further offend you than becomes

speaker: ORLANDO
text: me for my good.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Get you with him, you old dog.

speaker: ADAM
text: Is “old dog” my reward? Most true, I have lost

speaker: ADAM
text: my teeth in your service. God be with my old

speaker: ADAM
text: master. He would not have spoke such a word.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Is it even so? Begin you to grow upon me? I

speaker: OLIVER
text: will physic your rankness, and yet give no thousand

speaker: OLIVER
text: crowns neither.—Holla, Dennis!

speaker: DENNIS
text: Calls your Worship?

speaker: OLIVER
text: Was not Charles, the Duke’s wrestler, here to

speaker: OLIVER
text: speak with me?

speaker: DENNIS
text: So please you, he is here at the door and

speaker: DENNIS
text: importunes access to you.

speaker: OLIVER
text:
Call him in.
                 
                Dennis
                 
                exits
                .
               ’Twill be a good

speaker: OLIVER
text: way, and tomorrow the wrestling is.

speaker: CHARLES
text: Good morrow to your Worship.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Good Monsieur Charles, what’s the new news

speaker: OLIVER
text: at the new court?

speaker: CHARLES
text: There’s no news at the court, sir, but the old

speaker: CHARLES
text: news. That is, the old duke is banished by his

speaker: CHARLES
text: younger brother the new duke, and three or four

speaker: CHARLES
text: loving lords have put themselves into voluntary

speaker: CHARLES
text: exile with him, whose lands and revenues enrich

speaker: CHARLES
text: the new duke. Therefore he gives them good leave

speaker: CHARLES
text: to wander.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Can you tell if Rosalind, the Duke’s daughter,

speaker: OLIVER
text: be banished with her father?

speaker: CHARLES
text: O, no, for the Duke’s daughter her cousin so

speaker: CHARLES
text: loves her, being ever from their cradles bred together,

speaker: CHARLES
text: that she would have followed her exile or have

speaker: CHARLES
text: died to stay behind her. She is at the court and no

speaker: CHARLES
text: less beloved of her uncle than his own daughter,

speaker: CHARLES
text: and never two ladies loved as they do.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Where will the old duke live?

speaker: CHARLES
text: They say he is already in the Forest of Arden,

speaker: CHARLES
text: and a many merry men with him; and there they

speaker: CHARLES
text: live like the old Robin Hood of England. They say

speaker: CHARLES
text: many young gentlemen flock to him every day and

speaker: CHARLES
text: fleet the time carelessly, as they did in the golden

speaker: CHARLES
text: world.

speaker: OLIVER
text: What, you wrestle tomorrow before the new

speaker: OLIVER
text: duke?

speaker: CHARLES
text: Marry, do I, sir, and I came to acquaint you

speaker: CHARLES
text: with a matter. I am given, sir, secretly to understand

speaker: CHARLES
text: that your younger brother Orlando hath a

speaker: CHARLES
text: disposition to come in disguised against me to try a

speaker: CHARLES
text: fall. Tomorrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit, and he

speaker: CHARLES
text: that escapes me without some broken limb shall

speaker: CHARLES
text: acquit him well. Your brother is but young and

speaker: CHARLES
text: tender, and for your love I would be loath to foil

speaker: CHARLES
text: him, as I must for my own honor if he come in.

speaker: CHARLES
text: Therefore, out of my love to you, I came hither to

speaker: CHARLES
text: acquaint you withal, that either you might stay him

speaker: CHARLES
text: from his intendment, or brook such disgrace well

speaker: CHARLES
text: as he shall run into, in that it is a thing of his own

speaker: CHARLES
text: search and altogether against my will.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Charles, I thank thee for thy love to me, which

speaker: OLIVER
text: thou shalt find I will most kindly requite. I had

speaker: OLIVER
text: myself notice of my brother’s purpose herein, and

speaker: OLIVER
text: have by underhand means labored to dissuade him

speaker: OLIVER
text: from it; but he is resolute. I’ll tell thee, Charles, it is

speaker: OLIVER
text: the stubbornest young fellow of France, full of

speaker: OLIVER
text: ambition, an envious emulator of every man’s good

speaker: OLIVER
text: parts, a secret and villainous contriver against me

speaker: OLIVER
text: his natural brother. Therefore use thy discretion. I

speaker: OLIVER
text: had as lief thou didst break his neck as his finger.

speaker: OLIVER
text: And thou wert best look to ’t, for if thou dost him

speaker: OLIVER
text: any slight disgrace, or if he do not mightily grace

speaker: OLIVER
text: himself on thee, he will practice against thee by

speaker: OLIVER
text: poison, entrap thee by some treacherous device,

speaker: OLIVER
text: and never leave thee till he hath ta’en thy life by

speaker: OLIVER
text: some indirect means or other. For I assure thee—

speaker: OLIVER
text: and almost with tears I speak it—there is not one so

speaker: OLIVER
text: young and so villainous this day living. I speak but

speaker: OLIVER
text: brotherly of him, but should I anatomize him to

speaker: OLIVER
text: thee as he is, I must blush and weep, and thou must

speaker: OLIVER
text: look pale and wonder.

speaker: CHARLES
text: I am heartily glad I came hither to you. If he

speaker: CHARLES
text: come tomorrow, I’ll give him his payment. If ever

speaker: CHARLES
text: he go alone again, I’ll never wrestle for prize more.

speaker: CHARLES
text: And so God keep your Worship.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Farewell, good Charles.

speaker: OLIVER
text: Now will I stir this gamester. I hope I shall see an

speaker: OLIVER
text: end of him, for my soul—yet I know not why—

speaker: OLIVER
text: hates nothing more than he. Yet he’s gentle, never

speaker: OLIVER
text: schooled and yet learned, full of noble device, of all

speaker: OLIVER
text: sorts enchantingly beloved, and indeed so much in

speaker: OLIVER
text: the heart of the world, and especially of my own

speaker: OLIVER
text: people, who best know him, that I am altogether

speaker: OLIVER
text: misprized. But it shall not be so long; this wrestler

speaker: OLIVER
text: shall clear all. Nothing remains but that I kindle the

speaker: OLIVER
text: boy thither, which now I’ll go about.
